environments/enable-stf.yaml.message: The idea behind enable-stf was to have only one environment file to pull in for enabling STF. If that changed, we should probably have a documentation note
Since you are changing a feature in a way that users should notice, it should have a releasenote here for tht.

IIRC, you use reno[1]

For content, I'd probably take the information that you have in the comments and include that in the note. IMHO the ``prelude`` and ``other`` section should be populated, as I don't think this fits in the other sections.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/reno/2.5.0/user/usage.html
How is a releasenote created for that?

That's fine. Documentation can be adjusted, but won't be related to this PR. Documentation lives with the STF project. The idea of not including all the services here is that it will allow for set up of the data collection, but not be biased strongly towards the data collectors and transport architecture. For example, in the future this file could be used with qdr-mesh-mode and not require an enable-stf-mesh.yaml.

I'll probably just put the resources back in to this file to make this all much simpler. I'm just afraid it will box us in to a corner in the future if we decide to change the deployment model (or provide flexibility around deployment models).
In connection with legacy telemetry, using such a low polling interval is a recipe for disaster. Can you make that 60 instead of 5?

Gnocchi can not handle 5 secs polling interval. But also collecting info from polled services may take longer. Not sure how loaded your test env. has been. While I am thinking about this, that may also be a reason for Leonids large gaps, because polling and answers are colliding. It would be worth a try to change that, or to try to see if increasing the interval has a positive effect on gaps i ceilometer metrics.
I feel like 60 seconds is too long, so maybe I'll split it and make it 30 seconds to start. I don't know, whatever we pick here is basically just a random pick out of the air regardless.

Is it a disaster because Gnocchi couldn't deal with that level of interval, or because of other reasons? I've been running this polling interval for a few months now and not noticed any issues on the OSP deployment, and my deployments are virtualized with limited resources.

since this should not be different from settings without stf, can we make sure these are updated for ceilometer directly, please?

There is https://github.com/openstack/puppet-ceilometer/blob/master/manifests/params.pp#L19-L50

Well we're already overriding defaults for functionality to support STF, and this file is specifically for enabling STF data collection, so I'm not sure why this would be different from overriding different defaults.

Also changing defaults have other complications that could break systems, so backporting them will be much more complicated than keeping our specific expected configuration for STF delivery where someone opts in to that configuration rather than forcing it on everyone regardless of STF usage or not.

These values could also further change in the future as we gather more information and build dashboards etc in our external application. I'm not sure I feel comfortable changing the defaults.

If there is a bugfix or a change to improve settings, they should be changed in general imho, and not just for the case of using stf. I would also prefer only one location instead of having multiple locations for configuration.
Why should these not be different?

There has been a suggestion that we should actually keep the resource_registry here instead of using existing environment files because this could potentially cause a regression and we should note that some how.

Personally I feel like no one is going to be using this unless they are using STF, and we're not referencing this file in STF documentation, so I'm not sure why anyone would be using this at all currently.

So I'm not really sure what to do here. Leave it how I have it now for better flexibility about the data transmission vs how we collect data (this file), or put the resources back in to be specific and avoid a (low probability?) regression?
I think I've convinced myself that I'm going to remove the resource_registry like I have done here and add a release note
Should we stop collecting at 5 second intervals on collectd and bump this to 30 seconds as well?
Ack

I originally had the ceilometer polling interval at 5s, then Matthias suggested it should be 60s, so I picked something in the middle since we were just picking random numbers anyways. Suggestion was only to pick something consistent.

We could actually have a high polling frequency in collectd and only transmit every 30s (or some other random number) which we could make use of with the threshold plugin for localized events that would react faster than the full northbound loop through storage, threshold, and alert via Alertmanager, but that's a whole different discussion.

So mostly it's an open question. Only reason I thought about raising it was because we're not really doing anything with the fast sampling AMQP interval, so we could potentially scale to more nodes by reducing the number of sent messages.

For ceilometer I don't actually know what value to set this to since there hasn't been any benchmarking against ceilometer polling intervals and the possible straight it might put on rabbitmq. Since we're using sg-core everywhere as of STF 1.3, the slower polling interval on ceilometer doesn't seem to to bother sg-core even though it is scraped every 10s on the data store side.

Emma did note how a release note could be created, but I'm not sure how to backport release notes (or if that's a thing?). I'd like to backport this all the way to Train to align with the target OSP version we're using with STF.
Is there a particular reason you are suggesting that? If it's to match the ceilometer polling interval - is there a compelling reason its 30s and not 5s?

> Emma did note how a release note could be created, but I'm not sure how to backport release notes (or if that's a thing?). I'd like to backport this all the way to Train to align with the target OSP version we're using with STF.

The release note is created as a text file that you add to the commit. Once you backport this change that will go with it.

CONTRIBUTING.rst.message:
This is not quite the same as the previous link. It is the source code, while we need to link to the generated documentation.

Apparently, the way these files are generated has changed, there used to be a file per module, now there is a file per package (check the generated doc/source/contributor/api to see what I mean). I think to fix it you only need to add `apidoc_separate_modules = True` to doc/source/conf.py (see https://github.com/sphinx-contrib/apidoc/blob/master/README.rst_

Furthermore, this is an internal link. I suggest we use this patch as a chance to stop using global links for internal locations. One of the way to link to another document is :doc:`/path/to/document` right in the text. So in this case ".... defined in :doc:`/contributor/api/ironic.inspector.base` and overwrite ..." (I'm omitting the "module" word because the link title already has it - see for yourself). This separate URL definition can then be removed.

collectd-extensions/src/python_plugins.c.message:
I assume this is fine since it would potentially only impact python2 based on the docs.
I can't tell from the docs, if this even had an impact on py3.

Encoding Name
The default encoding for Unicode objects you pass to collectd. If you omit this option it will default to ascii on Python 2. On Python 3 it will always be utf-8, as this function was removed, so this will be silently ignored. These defaults are hardcoded in Python and will ignore everything else, including your locale.

It only works for python2 deployments.
It should not be cherry-picked for backports to python2 deployments.
collectd python3 plugins always use utf-8 encoding so collectd will complain and fail at startup if it encounters the Encoding configuration line. On the centos8 image at least, it does not silently ignore it.

Let me try to answer these comments together:

We need to decide if we allow packet forwarding from one external gw port to another external gw port ("external-external traffic" for short). A router by default forwards packets between all of its ports. Including external-external traffic. So if we add multiple external ports and do nothing else, then we allowed external-external traffic. I don't need external-external traffic. But I also don't see a problem in allowing external-external traffic. So I'm okay with both.

If we have a reason to prohibit external-external traffic, that needs additional work (rules to drop that traffic). And I'm not sure that additional work is worth doing. If you see a reason to prohibit external-external traffic, please let me know and I will change the spec. However if we don't have a reason to prohibit external-external traffic, then I propose to do the simpler thing: let the external-external traffic flow.
Sorry, I'm lost again.
Please see my answer in line 56.

Will there be any criteria for selecting the special one?
Also, since we support the update_external_gateways operation, will there be reselection of the special, after update operation?

Kind of. Not like a pointer though.

In the proposal a router has:

* an external_gateway_info attribute which contains a single external gw
* an external_gateways attribute which contains a list of external gws

The one external gw that is in the external_gateway_info is always duplicated as the first element of the external_gateways list.

This element (which is in the external_gateway_info and in external_gateways[0]) is the special one. So the API user can decide which one is the special. And also can send updates that change which one is special.
I like that as this will make our api 100% backward compatible so we will not break anything 😊
That's the plan at least. 😊
good, so we don't really need any db schema changes, right?
Yep.

The more I look at the l3-agent code, the less sure I am I have a grand plan other than making the necessary changes here and there. So maybe I'll just remove this section, so it does not block the API review. I don't think anything we change in the agent could have an effect on the API proposal.

To be honest, I see this description a bit misleading. This is talking about active-active HA routers but then the implementation will modify only centralized routers; HA routers are out of scope in this spec. Right?

Sorry for that, it wasn't my intention to mislead.

We are in a discussion with a vendor that wants to use this API to actually support active-active routers. However I don't have control over whether that implementation gets open sourced or not.

Here I was trying to find the smallest possible upstream change, that makes sense in itself and at the same time enables that vendor (and of course any other future vendor) to support active-active routers (at least if interconnected like pictured below).

That's why my use case is about active-active routers, but then the implementation is not. Does that make sense? Is it okay?
Yes, I was trying to be clear on the concepts.
Can you describe the routing table with more than one GW?
Yeah, I saw it but I wanted to see how you will deal with this multiple GW in the routing table. I'll wait for the implementation.

I made the paragraphs below more precise. Also reorganized a bit so the description is not totally in the 'Out of Scope' section. Please let me know if that describes the routing table as you would like to see or please tell me what you find unclear.
So if "external_gateway_info" is deleted (main GW interface), the other external GWs in this router will be automatically deleted too.
Yes, exactly.
Thanks

zuul/zk/executor.py.message: I think you may need to set default values for data and stat to None. If you don't then the exception that can be raised below means they won't be set. Then on lines 56 and 64 we may have problems with undefined names.

I don't think we need to guard against that?  It's just a couple of duplicate lines (it's okay to remove the listener twice; it's just a set discard).

To be clear, the ZooKeeper watch is removed regardless of what we do here because we haven't called a method to add it (removing the 'retry' is what does this).  The remove_listener call just stops the watcher from being re-added after a disconnect.

This class never creates a watcher on a non-existent path, because the get call doesn't succeed so the watcher isn't set.  However, we are registered as a client-side connection listener, so on a disconnect, we'll be called and will attempt again.

I think the current code is correct because in all cases it leaves us without a watch and without a connection listener.

This block is not necessary if the user supplied callback returned False for some reason: https://github.com/python-zk/kazoo/blob/master/kazoo/recipe/watchers.py#L165-L168

This would also remove a watcher that was created on a non existing path. If you want the callback to be able to decide if it should return False and stop watching then you should defer this to the callback.

However, if we want to ensure no watching happens on non existing nodes (seems like a reasonable thing specifically for zuul in this case) then we should probably guard against this more robustly:

  if stat is None and not self._stopped:
      #cleanup

I had missed that the exists call was necessary to set a watch on a non existent path. Though now I remember you saying that this behavior is why you think they had the code there in the first place.

Given that I think this code is correct as long as we don't want to defer to DELETE event callbacks to decide if the path should continue to be watched. Asserting this is a watcher for a path that exists until the path does not exist seems like a fine tool since that is what zuul needs.

Last thought is we might want to vendor the entire parent class in this definition to avoid issues with private methods changing. Otherwise I think this is good.

For example, suppose you've got a policy that started out with part power 16 and you've increased it to 17 then 18. during PPI relink the old part power isn't really 'stale' - that's where client requests are directed - so might be best to avoid giving the impression that the file is somehow state and no longer needed

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm sorry to post this, because I know how much effort you've put here.. but this has to be solved on the SQLAlchemy side. I don't feel okay with adding a bunch of code only you truly understand to the critical path.

Have you tried talking to Mike Bayer aka zzzeek? I cannot image we're the only one who suffers from this issue.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Dmitry, this literally cannot be just magically solved on the sqlalchemy side. The SQLAlchemy docs are rather explicit which is where if you use ORM as ironic does, these are the ways it works. With the size of the nodes table, we ultimately don't have much of a choice *except* to follow the explicitly documented pattern and query the specific columns instead of requesting full object re-hydration. Think 9 steps as opposed to 55 standard fields per node, or something like 59 with a traits joined view (as is required for the node list).

https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/faq/performance.html#result-fetching-slowness-orm

Additional behavior context at covering the fact that ORM generated queries generally fetchall() before returning: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/faq/performance.html#result-fetching-slowness-core

I'll happily reach out to zzzeek, but unfortunately if I've interpretted the docs and our situation correctly, we're facing our literal only path which is really not that complex. The hardest thing was actually figuring out there wasn't another magical way.

Months or years from now, developers who may not be all the same people here today may have to revisit this code for whatever reason and will be looking for the rationale in how it was modified here.    Towards that scenario, I would like to suggest that this introductory paragraph as well as parts of the steps below are misleading.   As I've referred to in earlier comments, SQLAlchemy's ORM loading behavior is a default behavior with direct APIs to alter it in a fine-grained way, so I would disagree with the characterization of this behavior as an "issue";   the list of fields SQLAlchemy returns is directly controlled using the load_only() loader option.  I've also suggested APIs that perform the task of emitting a SELECT query that's merged among a set of primary keys using "IN" directly.   

While I have no problem with the developer preference here to replace SQLAlchemy's higher level APIs with a more verbose approach, the rationale for this much complexity, including  basic things like not using the "select()" construct in favor of "text()" (which IMO needs to be revised or replaced in any case due to the SQL injection vulnerability introduced), remains unclear to me, and I would like to see that "limitations in SQLAlchemy" are not named here as that rationale, as this kind of messaging only makes my job harder in other areas as the person tasked with making sure developer teams are using these libraries appropriately.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I think we're not using the same words, and clearly we're focusing on different things. Reading your words, I get your viewing my effort as an threat or attack. It is not intended as such. I'm simply trying to do the needful to reduce the amount of overhead to improve performance. Rather substantially improve performance at that. For what is is worth, I have literally attempted everything you have suggested in terms of strategy to keep everything using ORM objects and returned resulting objects. 

Unfortunately we're down to mechanics of being returned an sqlalchemy object.

I guess in part it is like the fog of war, except it is the blinders of frustration, mixed with contextual disconnects.

Further down in this commit message, I posted a reply to your comment on line 29. I think that should shed more light for you in terms of the disconnect we're encountering between us. Contents of the result set when accessed, comprising the entire row's contents:
{'created_at': datetime.datetime(2021, 5, 27, 18, 23, 5, 247023), 'updated_at': None, 'version': '1.35', 'id': 1, 'uuid': '73785490-3038-4572-853f-83aeac0fece9', 'instance_uuid': None, 'name': None, 'chassis_id': None, 'power_state': None, 'target_power_state': None, 'provision_state': 'available', 'target_provision_state': None, 'provision_updated_at': None, 'last_error': None, 'instance_info': {'configdrive': 'TG9yZW0gaXBzdW0gZG9sb3Igc2l0IGFtZXQ=', 'image_url': 'http://example.com/test_image_url', 'foo': 'bar'}, 'properties': {'cpu_arch': 'x86_64', 'cpus': '8', 'local_gb': '10', 'memory_mb': '4096'}, 'driver': 'fake-hardware', 'driver_info': {'foo': 'bar', 'fake_password': 'fakepass'}, 'driver_internal_info': {'cat': 'meow'}, 'clean_step': {}, 'deploy_step': {}, 'resource_class': 'CUSTOM_BAREMETAL', 'raid_config': {}, 'target_raid_config': {}, 'reservation': None, 'conductor_affinity': None, 'conductor_group': '', 'maintenance': False, 'maintenance_reason': None, 'fault': None, 'console_enabled': False, 'inspection_finished_at': None, 'inspection_started_at': None, 'extra': {}, 'automated_clean': None, 'protected': False, 'protected_reason': None, 'owner': 'fred', 'lessee': 'marsha', 'allocation_id': None, 'description': None, 'bios_interface': None, 'boot_interface': None, 'console_interface': None, 'deploy_interface': 'purring_machine', 'inspect_interface': None, 'management_interface': None, 'network_interface': None, 'raid_interface': None, 'rescue_interface': None, 'retired': False, 'retired_reason': None, 'network_data': {}, 'storage_interface': None, 'power_interface': None, 'vendor_interface': None}

so not to complicate this but a much more efficient way to get related collections is to run a separate query agianst "NodeTrait" directly, of the form:

   SELECT <cols> FROM node_trait WHERE node_id IN (...list of node ids that you just fetched....)

SQLAlchemy has an eager loading strategy called "selectinload" that uses this approach.  It is generally much superior to "joinedload" for collections because it does not require an expensive LEFT OUTER JOIN at all, and additionally does not require sending the original Node columns for a certain Node primary key over the wire over and over again.   you could try this strategy directly first, or perhaps in conjunction with load_only() to reduce the fetched columns.

ironic/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
I guess this is one of those things that if we try to make it super similar and developer friendly, we're also going to make it slower, so we need to choose carefully and benchmark every path we try to take. Also, there are a couple different paths, some may not work as well as others of course. FWIW, this stack at present was ~513 nodes/second on my desktop with my test data set.

So the ORM Query class object would be a different use pattern, and it is apparently legal usage per SQLAlchemy docs that doesn't explicitly require a session. So we could take the prepared statement, and inject the list of ids, and maybe that would be more similar without the canned SQL, but I think we would still be dealing with the list directly as the query is a prepared statement coming out of the query builder. I don't know, that feels like a lot to effectively do the exact same thing as the sql text does. :\

Alternatively we could fire up a new ORM query object with a new session, and maybe have it handle the list entirely and run the query, however depending on how we end up doing that, even with prepared sql, we need to provide the whole object model, and we're returned a list of sqlalchemy objects which will require additional overhead, and if we stray into touching one of the un-needed fields somehow, we trigger additional queries. Also, again, all running in transactions with the sql server when not needed as we don't need to have any guarantees the data won't change as we're just grabbing a snapshot view of it, and leveraging prepared statements, and squashing the prior session... which I guess is okay as well, just higher overhead. The downside to this is we'll need to explicitly extract the specific values we need while not touching the created_at and updated_at fields to prevent those items from being individually queried on the objects back to the database. Anyway, extract the values, assemble it into a Munch object per node so we don't break the object model access as Munch can't just munch a sqlalchemy object... and even if it could it would still incur a query for the two not retrieved fields on the model that we don't need nor want.

So, any thoughts? I can try the query object to the read only engine connection, which afaik doesn't try to request a transaction for every query it is running.

ironic/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
So, actually, I don't think we can do it in just one pass, but not for the immediate reason you may be thinking.

We *have* to have the 'traits' field in the result set on each node. So no matter what, there is our second pass to at a minimum check every row, ensure it is set properly, and then package it as a Munch. We do that as one final action with the lookup now. We could possibly inject on the first pass, then check, reconcile, and then package the Munch on a second pass. 

But there is a key aspect to also keep in mind, there is no guarantee a node has traits, so there may be no entry in the result set.

To make matters worse, traits inside the object are lists of objects until they hit the API where they are converted to a list of traits (Why did we do this to ourselves?!?) So the upfront pattern for injection would be "find associated node's position from a reference table, insert/append munch into list on the node (This feels like it would be a heavier operation to do for every single trait) since for every single trait row, we may end up hitting the larger node entries multiple times to get/check/append to list on field in node.

0-?50? traits per node. I feel like the average I've seen mentioned is either 0, or like 5-6 traits per node. If there was 6 traits per node, injection would be 6000 dictionary lookups, where as the existing code would be 1000 dictionary entry lookups with a fairly tight processing loop.

I wonder if a case could exist where out-of-date traits would get somehow re-written to the API. I know when we did a lot of this type of optimization in sqlalchemy at a previous job, we unearthed a lot of unexpected writes. Not really specific review feedback, just something to ponder.
Do traits get out-of-date? I couldn't find any information about "expiration" for a trait...

Since we're just grabbing a snapshot, I don't think we're really risking anything and actually providing possibly the most up to date information for the API client. Where as previously, with the transaction, I *think* we actually risked not sending the most up to date information depending on how long the transaction was running. But realistically what was happening under the hood was really complex and inefficient as it was doing tons of un-needed work.

But Iury is right, Traits don't expire. They are long lived pieces of data set by a human or computer operator.

just a note, "prepared statements" has a specific meaning in SQL [1], which is that of a SQL statement that is passed to the server which then produces a "handle" that can be used repeatedly with different sets of parameters.  The Pymysql driver used by Openstack as well as the general case of MySQL Python drivers do not use prepared statements.

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prepared_statement

tests/unit/test_scheduler.py.message:
If the scheduler is disconnected from ZK, then we would expect the request to be lost (since a request is an ephemeral node).  Therefore, the scheduler needs to resubmit the request.  I think that's true before and with this change, so I think this test is still correct.

But with this change, that should only happen if the executor has not yet accepted the nodes.  Once it has, then the scheduler should not resubmit.  We should make sure to add a test case to cover that (something like this one, but perform the disconnect/reconnect after the job starts running).

We may eventually want to make node requests non-ephemeral, as right now they need to be recreated if a scheduler crashes and an executor hasn't accepted them.

This (and the history list below) is what needed to change due to the new test.

The current behavior has us performing a RETRY if we report a gearman disconnect, but since this change moves retry handling to the executor, that's no longer possible.

This will be a behavior change is that jobs will have DISCONNECT reported as a result instead of being retried, but it's pretty rare that the scheduler disconnects from gearman, and this is all going away *very* soon once the build requests are moved to ZK.

The job class is part of the executor.  It's the part that handles the stuff that's specific to the job.  I think the locking should happen there so that the executor's main thread can get back to its work.  Think of it as a fork and exec model (with threads).  The executor does the minimum necessary to start a new thread to handle the build request, and then hands it off to the child thread.  You can see this method is all there is -- there is almost no work done in this method.

For that reason, I do think we should move this to the job class.

Ok, I will give it another try. I thought that the NodeRequest.priority might change during runtime (since it's a property function), but it looks like it's only used in submitNodeRequest. So it should be possible to move this to the manager as well.
Ok, then I will do this in a follow-up change

It seems to be a little more complicated: The pausedParent() call is also used in the priority property of the node request, which means we can't simply move this part to the pipeline manager. In addition to that the NodesProvisionedEvent handling (Scheduler._doNodesProvisionedEvent) is also relying on the build_set and job being set on the node request. The latter one could be solved by just storing the build_set_uuid and job_name on the node request and iterate over all queue items to find the matching build_set (which we also do for the result events that are stored in ZK by now).

This change relies on the nodeset being part of the node request, but that's not part of the zuul/nodepool protocol.  The quick-start tests are failing because Nodepool does not know anything about the nodeset attribute, so it strips it from zk when it writes.  The unit tests don't catch this because their simplified simulated nodepool does rewrite the complete object.

We really shouldn't change anything about the NodeRequest object.  But we shouldn't need to: the nodeset is part of the build parameters, so on the executor side, we can get the nodeset structure from that and fill in the nodes from the node request.

Ultimately, any scheduler needs to be able to de-serialize the node request, so we're either going to need to stop storing the extra information on the node request (since nodepool will delete it), or change nodepool so that it copies over the extra data.

I would prefer the first option, since this is really Nodepool's API.

To do that, we need to be able to associate a node request with the buildset+job it was requested for.  We have a dictionary of node requests in the buildset object, so one way of doing that would be to iterate over all the queue items in all the pipelines in all the tenants and look for the node request in that dictionary.  That would work, but eventually any scheduler is going to need to be able to respond to any fulfilled node request, so there could be a lot of iteration involved.  The first step of getting the event to the right pipeline event queue is the main issue -- once it's in the right pipeline event queue, iterating over the pipeline isn't a big deal.

To make that process more efficient, we could put an index in zookeeper to map the node requests to buildsets+jobs, however that seems a bit excessive.  It sounds like we have a good use case for adding an extra piece of information to the node request in ZK.

We might consider using the "requestor" field for that, however, nodepool does use that for statistics purposes, so we should probably leave that alone.

How about we add a "requestor_data" field, so that requestors can encode information about the request?  From nodepool's perspective, it would be opaque data.  We could put the tenant, pipeline, buildset, and job in there.

I don't think this has to happen as part of this change, but we should get started on that soon.
I'd also go for the opaque data in a dedicated field in the NodeRequest. That sounds like an appropriate solution. "requestor_data" sounds good.
That sounds good to me. There are a lot of apis out there that allow to pass opaque data which is returned by the api again. So this is not an uncommon pattern.
Note the nodeset value appears to be set by getNodeRequest() after constructing this class.

zuul/nodepool.py.message:
A gearman job seems like the wrong thing to be passing into this.  How about either the AnsibleJob, or we could create a temporary "Build" class that has all the same info (which we construct from the job arguments), then switch it for the real zuul.model.Build later once we have that in ZK?

Incidentally, this change has convinced me that once we have the build in ZK, we should remove the arguments from the BuildRequest and just reference the Build from it.

> A gearman job seems like the wrong thing to be passing into this

I thought the same, but it was the least thing I could provide without changing too much. In combination with your comment on https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/774610/5/zuul/executor/server.py#3131 it might be a start to use the AnsibleJob here instead and see where this leads us. As long as the build itself is not in ZK, I would like to avoid having another "build-like" object with the same params in another stack of changes.
I think this question may be moot; see below.

If you delete a node request without locking the nodes, the Nodepool will notice that, lock the nodes, and reallocate them.  It may mostly work most of the time because that's a periodic action, but I think every few minutes, you would probably see nodepool go through and reallocate a bunch of node requests right before executors tried to start.

In the nodepool protocol, nodes must be locked before the request is deleted.  So I think what we need to do is leave this method as-is, and remove its invocation from the scheduler, then let the pipeline manager see that the request is fulfilled and therefore it's ready to submit a build request.  Then the executor should call this method instead of the "lock + use" that you currently have.

It's true that there are attributes of the NodeRequest which aren't serialized to ZK, but I don't think they're important; they are mostly used to deal with potentialy issues with the async nature of ZK requests and Zuul's main event loop.

However, I don't think any of the "extra" stuff on the NodeRequest object is important.  I think it should be enough to simply pass the node request path to the executor with the build request, instantiate a NodeRequest object from ZK, and call acceptNodes on that.  Some of the checks at the start may not be very relevant anymore.

The executor should also delete the node request when it locks the nodes.  The scheduler should be fine with that: it will have stopped watching the node request once it was fulfilled, and it will be removed from the buildset from onNodesProvisioned so it won't try to update it any more.

The function that cleans up orphaned buildrequests should also make sure that it deletes linked noderequests as well.

I tried to move the acceptNodes() call to the executor side, but I'm a little stuck there.

The main reason is: To call the acceptNodes() on the executor, I would have to provide the NodeRequest object to the executor. Although most of the NodeRequest data is stored in ZooKeeper, there is a lot ongoing on the NodeRequest object itself which is not persisted to ZooKeeper. Thus, I would have to fully serialize the NodeRequest first to be able to restore a "rich" NodeRequest object on the executor side that can be used to interact with the local NodePool API.

I have already started with this in a follow-up change (not pushed to gerrit yet) where I switch the NodePool API from the "in-place NodeRequest update" (which updates the local NodeRequest object with fresh data from ZooKeeper) to a TreeCache. But I would like to keep that change on top of this one, because I think it's simpler to update the NodePool API when the node locking is done in the executor.

I can try to move parts out of the follow-up change into this one to make the NodeRequest fully serializable. Maybe doing that is also worth a change on its own, but I currently cannot see the whole impact of this change. When this is done, we might be able to keep the acceptNodes() method like it is.

I hope this was somewhat understandable. Please let me know if anything is unclear or if you have a better idea. Maybe I'm also missing some important point.

Ok. This would mean that we remove this call from the scheduler https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/scheduler.py#L1796 but have to find another way to tell the pipeline manager that the job is ready for execution?
Agreed; I don't see a way for this to happen.
I think this is similar to the above, yes.  An internal state change within the scheduler which doesn't apply any more.

This (and the other methods) really should take a Build instance instead of AnsibleJob, but we don't have builds in ZK yet.

I don't think AnsibleJob is used anywhere outside of the executor, and it would be nice to keep it that way; it's complicated enough without trying to serve other use cases.  Can you either switch this to take a bunch of individual arguments, or add a TODO to switch to using Build when it's available?

I've added a TODO. I found that a little more appropriate since we would otherwise have to substitute the build/ansible_job parameter with 5 other parameters and move the logic to get those parameters out into the caller method.

It might be better to call this method "checkNodeRequest" since it doesn't actually accept anything; it's mostly a bunch of sanity checks (or possibly a resubmit).  That may help avoid confusions since "accepting" is a pretty well defined concept in the nodepool protocol.

zuul/executor/server.py.message:
Based on chatting in IRC, it sounds like you're using network_cli only because it doesn't run the setup playbook.  We don't actually know whether this is a problem for normal network_cli usage, so I don't think we should merge this change.

For your use case, I would recommend adding a new type of "resource" like "namespace" or "project".  Then we won't add them to the zuul inventory at all.

Instead of doing this, can we set gather_facts to false in the freeze playbook (since presumably we have gathered them (if possible) already during setup)?

Because if we don't run the freeze playbook, then we won't have any job variables available for a host.

The use case, is we want them in the inventory file but not to run commands from zuul-executor until we have configured the node.  The use case I am thinking of, we need to SSH into a private IP from another node in the nodeset, to properly configure the public interface so that zuul-executor can start to use it.

Right now, we have no way of opting out of this scan when we split it out from the setup playbooks.

So, I agree a new resource is likely needed, but I'd like to also support the use-case above.

A lot of this is network specific hardware where we cannot easily do provision things via cloud-init or glean.  And usually need to run raw commands to start.

To support your specific use case could the workflow be something like:

* Zuul manages new resource, doesn't put it in the inventory but does put it in zuul vars.
* Write a zuul role to provision that new resource so that it is able to talk to ansible
* Manually add these resources to the inventory in your playbooks as necessary to talk to them.
You should set freeze=True here, because as it's written, you're passing remove_keys=True.  (ed: not applicable any more).

Thanks, for fixing this! I knew that late binding behavior would hit me at some point :D

I think `functools.partial()` could also work here:

     self.kazoo_client.ChildrenWatch(
         pipelines_path,

Is this argument necessary if we aren't sending events?
It's not, but I liked having the full standard function signature so it doesn't matter.

I know it was this way before but its a bit weird to have both trigger and management events in the same zookeeper path which is analogous to having them all in one queue there then we split them out here into two different queues.

I guess we use a prefix on the znodes rather than separating them into different paths. Is there a specific reason we do that? This sort of thing might be worth calling out in the code?

Yes, the different event types are separated by using different prefixes. I guess the main reason was that it's described like this in the spec, but it also simplifies the watches. Otherwise we'd need three instead of one data watch for every pipeline/tenant event queue.

Thank you for confirming it is to simplify watches. I think that is a reasonable enough reason for the "cohosting" of the queues on the zookeeper side. It just jumped uot to me as potentially odd so wanted to call it out. Sounds like there is a good reason for it though.

tests/base.py.message:
This solves a race condition which could lead to a test being settled to early because this whole if block evaluates to True, but there are still result events in ZooKeeper.

There could be a short timeframe in which the ZK event queues are empty, but the builds are just about to report their result. But when those results show up in ZK, the areZooKeeperEventQueuesEmpty() check was already successful. If the haveAllBuildsReported(9 check is now also successful (because the builds reported fast enough), the test will settle although there are still result events left in the queue. Putting the areZooKeeperEventQueuesEmpty() check to the end ensures that we catch all result events which might happen during the waitUntilSettled().

A share can be exported on multiple networks at the same time; consider a DHSS=False NetApp vServer with two data LIFs. In addition, we allow the possibility of an "admin" network for share migration. 

Would the human readable export be created on each of the networks configured?

Yeah, that's the initial idea... It can increase the amount of export locations a lot in scenarios where there are lots of lifs, but we'd be allowing users to be mounting the shares using each one of them...
This can default to the name of the share if not specified? Or are you expecting to not create human readable exports if this isn't provided?

Initially, I'm expecting to not create if the mount_point_name was not specified... In this way, users would be free to decide it...
Also because I thought about the following scenario:
User accidentally creates a share using a name that is currently being used by other share, and coincidentally the same share server/backend (in the DHSS=False case) is chosen by manila... If we were to reuse the name to create the human readable export location, a request that currently works perfectly would fail...
Do we have a clear definition of these?
It is good to mention.. but I'd say we should allow only underscores, or maybe if white spaces were provided, we could replace them by underscores.
We shouldn't be transforming these; validating and returning a HTTP BadRequest instead would be better user experience
Agreed...

What could go wrong with other shares operations like: replica and promotion of replica, share migration, etc. Could this new share attribute block those operations if not supported? Or just continue with the operation and the remove the custom export name if not supported (or in conflict with another existing export location, in the same share server).

In the case of replicas and promotion of replicas I think it should be okay, considering that active and inactive replicas wouldn't usually reside in different backend storages (i.e. wouldn't create a replica of my NetApp share in a Dell backend)
But for share migration, it would be nice to have this in the share type and possibly being reported by the backend, otherwise if a share is migrated from a backend that supports custom export locations to another that doesn't, the latter wouldn't be able to create the custom export location. In that case, I'd say we have two approaches:
1. Error the migration, claiming that the destination backend does not support such thing
2. Allow the migration to happen but add a LOG alleging that the custom export location won't be available in the destination.
I'd say I'm in favor of 2... Considering that we can not enforce all driver vendors to implement this because we are unsure that all of them would support such functionality.

I'm a bit concerned about the user experience here.  They will provide a custom_export_location at create time and get no error.  But it may be ignored depending on which back end is scheduled for the share creation.

Also, they may get an error later on if the custom_export_location that they have chosen is already in use on the scheduled back end.

Yeah, the UX will be a bit modified in the creation... But we can mitigate this with share type extra spec and the capability. We can fail a bit earlier if a mount_path_name was specified, and the share type says there's not support for it on its extra specs, but in case it matches the extra spec but there's no backend to handle it, it would fail in the scheduler. Still, it's earlier than the initial idea...
Yeah... Project renames shouldn't happen so often, and I think we can hazard relying on it...
For DHSS=False, we could avoid giving much details in the user message and get to a consensus...

I guess I assumed the UX to be a little different here; isn't it possible to introduce "human_readable_export_location_support" as a new tenant visible capability and ensure that this is set in the share type so that we can only schedule to backends where this workflow is possible?

Another concern is multitenancy - I see no problems with DHSS=True consumers being told "there's already an export with the name you're creating, so try another name" via an asynchronous user message; but, for DHSS=False, divulging this information is problematic. Is it possible to add some deduplication structure?

Project names are unique within a domain and known/friendly to end-users and can be used (however, you can rename projects - only the IDs are really unique - project renames don't happen every day though; so we can probably hazard using names?)

Since the API service needs to behave differently when this extra-spec is present, we should call out that this back end capability when set as a share type extra-spec is always tenant-visible.

Yeah, this should be an easy implementation to all the storage systems, but we do not have modifications foreseen to all share back end drivers, so vendors that want to implement this will need to modify their drivers to benefit from this functionality.
If they do not have this backend capability set, this can become misleading, considering the following scenario:

1. User request a share to be created, and specifies a --mount-point-name
2. Request is accepted
3. We forward it to the scheduler but it won't check any backend capability wrt this
4. The request is forwarded to a back end driver that didn't implement this functionality yet
5. The back end driver do not create the custom export location
6. Share becomes available, it has the `mount_point_name` field set, but it is not in the list of the shares' export locations.
7. User tries to mount the share using the mount_path_name but it doesn't work

It won't work because the share driver may not modified to handle such functionality, and we aren't going to be raising errors, neither telling the user that the custom export location couldn't be created.

The driver capability would be a way to distinguish drivers that support it and have implemented this functionality.

So this is one of the concerns that leads us to add this backend capability. It allows driver maintainers to explictly say if their drivers support such functionality and is expected that they modified their driver behavior to have this working.
Also, with this backend capability, we are able to fail earlier in the scheduler, in case a share type with such extra spec was provided, and there aren't backends that support such functionality.

i think back end capability `human_readable_export_location_support` is not a hard work for backend storage, To implement this function, just need to use new mount_point_name In place of share_instance_id when create share dir. so i think we can assume that all storage supports this feature. do we really need this new back end capability?
we just need to update function of `create_share` and `create_replica` in driver.
